title: Ekmanianthe
text:
Ekmanianthe is a <a href="genus">genus</a> of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s in the <a href="Family%20%28biology%29">family</a> <a href="Bignoniaceae">Bignoniaceae</a>. It is <a href="sister%20taxon">most closely related</a> to "<a href="Tabebuia">Tabebuia</a>" and has sometimes been included within it. It consists of two <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="tree">tree</a>s, neither of which is especially <a href="Abundance%20%28ecology%29">common</a> in any part of its <a href="Range%20%28biology%29">range</a>. "<a href="Ekmanianthe%20longiflora">Ekmanianthe longiflora</a>" grows to in <a href="height">height</a> and is <a href="Indigenous%20%28ecology%29">native</a> to <a href="Haiti">Haiti</a> and the rocky <a href="Highland">uplands</a> of central <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a>. "<a href="Ekmanianthe%20actinophylla">Ekmanianthe actinophylla</a>" is a smaller tree, to in height, and it occurs in western Cuba where it is known as "roble caimán", for the resemblance of its <a href="Trunk%20%28botany%29">trunk</a> <a href="Bark%20%28botany%29">bark</a> to the <a href="Hide%20%28skin%29">hide</a> of a <a href="caiman">caiman</a>. "Roble" is a <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a> <a href="Common%20name">name</a> that is also applied to "Tabebuia". Neither of the species of "Ekmanianthe" is known in <a href="Gardening">cultivation</a>. The <a href="type%20species">type species</a> for "Ekmanianthe" is "E. longiflora". The <a href="wood">wood</a> of "Ekmanianthe" has been variously described as "soft" or as "very hard, heavy, and strong". Despite this, like many other <a href="Tecomeae">Tecomeae</a> species, it is rarely cultivated.
Description.
The following <a href="Species%20description">description</a> is based on two sources.
"Ekmanianthe actinophylla" is <a href="Cheiropterophily">cheiropterophilous</a> (bat-<a href="Pollination">pollinated</a>). "E. longiflora" has the long, narrow corolla tube that is typical of <a href="hawkmoth">hawkmoth</a>-<a href="Entomophily">pollinated</a> <a href="flower">flower</a>s.
The basally curved fruit of "Ekmanianthe" is a <a href="Synapomorphy">distinguishing feature</a>, clearly <a href="Segregate%20%28taxonomy%29">separating</a> that genus from "<a href="Tabebuia">Tabebuia</a>". The edge of the corolla is laciniate in a few <a href="moth">moth</a>-pollinated and a few <a href="bat">bat</a>-pollinated species of "Tabebuia", but much less so than in "Ekmanianthe". The <a href="lenticel">lenticel</a>s of "E. longiflora" and the <a href="Glossary%20of%20botanical%20terms%23Costa">costae</a> (ribs) on the fruit of "E. actinophylla" are more prominent than those of any species of "Tabebuia". The corolla tube of "E. longiflora" is longer than that of any species of "Tabebuia". "E. actinophylla" has 5 <a href="fertile">fertile</a> stamens, a <a href="Phenotypic%20trait">trait</a> not seen in "Tabebuia".
Evolution.
The <a href="Introduction%20to%20evolution">evolution</a> of "Ekmanianthe" is in some ways <a href="Parallel%20evolution">parallel</a> to that of the <a href="Asia">Asia</a>n <a href="Tribe%20%28biology%29">tribe</a> <a href="Oroxyleae">Oroxyleae</a>. The bat-pollinated "<a href="Oroxylum">Oroxylum</a>" has <a href="Floral%20symmetry">actinomorphic</a> flowers with five fertile stamens. The hawkmoth-pollinated "<a href="Nyctocalos">Nyctocalos</a>" has elongate flowers and most of the species have only four fertile stamens.
History.
Both species of "Ekmanianthe" were originally described in 1866 by <a href="August%20Grisebach">August Grisebach</a>, who placed them in the genus "<a href="Tecoma">Tecoma</a>". In 1915, <a href="Nathaniel%20Lord%20Britton">Nathaniel Lord Britton</a> placed them in "Tabebuia". In 1924, <a href="Ignatz%20Urban">Ignatz Urban</a>, recognizing their distinctiveness, erected the new genus "Ekmanianthe" in the <a href="Scientific%20journal">journal</a> now known as "<a href="Feddes%20Repertorium">Feddes Repertorium</a>", which was at that time edited by <a href="Friedrich%20Karl%20Georg%20Fedde">Friedrich Karl Georg Fedde</a>. "Ekmanianthe was <a href="Botanical%20name">named</a> for the <a href="Swedish%20people">Swedish</a> <a href="botanist">botanist</a> <a href="Erik%20Leonard%20Ekman">Erik Leonard Ekman</a> (1883-1931)."Anthe" is <a href="Etymology">derived</a> from a <a href="Greek%20language">Greek</a> word for "flower".
